ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about women's reproductive lives across cultures, how to critically think about the factors evolution has and hasn't played in how we conceive of women's reproductive lives, and have reflected on my own life.
I learned lot of biology I had never learned before. Amazing class
Learned so much about women's reproductive health.

I learned so much about my own body. I feel like this is information I will remember and cherish for the rest of my life, as we cover every stage of women's reproductive health. I feel very well-versed in this knowledge. I also learned so much about evolutionary thinking.
How to learn in a non traditional way.

The evolutionary processes behind milestone life experiences for female-bodied people like menstruation, pregnancy, and menopause. The variety of ways that cultures around the world experience these processesrelatedly, that "normal" is a construct. How to critically evaluate a pop science article. How to talk about my own life experiences in the context of evolutionary biology. Perhaps most importantly, learned that biological and cultural evolution, and biology and culture in general, are inextricably intertwinedhow you can't really study one without studying the other.

This is a PHENOMENAL CLASS. If you have the opportunity, you MUST take this class. I not only learned the complex mechanisms behind biological processes in the female body, but also the cultural and social meanings that come with them. I loved doing each and every reading -- I never wanted to miss a single class. I learned so much about my own body and the possible explanations for various functions. I also learned about the biological characteristics of women around the world and how they experience their biological womanhood. I was fascinated by the way our environments and lifestyles influence our biology.
So much. Learned a lot about important topics such as birth, labor, menstruation, etc. in a variety of different cultures and communities.
I learned so much, about our society, female bodies, and myself. I adored learning from Claudia and Sakura, and the entirety of the class.
Knowledge on my own body and its functions, skills on how to interact with scientific literature, insights on the global nature of menstruation and reproduction
I learned a comprehensive narrative about the female body.
This was an extremely enlightening class for anyone hoping to become in tune and knowledgeable about the power of their own female body.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I absolutely loved this course- no complaints! Professor Valeggia did such a great job in making the class a trusting environment where we all engaged, reflected, and learned each day.
Open environment, understanding teacher, and lots of fun projects. Weaknesses were that sometimes there was a definite answer and not a lot of dialogue on the other opinions.
Everything was great.

Strengths are Professor Valeggia's teaching methods, a low-stress environment that prioritizes learning over memorization, and an interactive student-led teaching style. Weaknesses are that for a leminar, I didn't feel very connected to classmates and the T&Q assignments become very repetitive.
No weaknesses. Only strengths. Great course.

I looked forward to this course every single week because of how engaging not only our seminar discussions on Wednesdays, but also Professor Valeggia's lectures on Mondays, were. Not only is this course's material fascinating, it is led in a way that centers student experiences, which allowed my peers to really get to know each other and to learn from and challenge one another. Almost every Wednesday seminar discussion is led by a different group of students (everyone gets the chance to co-lead one discussion), which kept things lively and different from week to week. The critique papers were a fantastic way to improve my ability to engage with scientific research, and I loved that we had the freedom to take the final project in any direction we wanted. Starting every class with meditation was also wonderful. There is really nothing I would change about this class!

Strengths -- The class was very well structured: we started with female anatomy, menarche, puberty and ended with menopause and aging. I was so impressed by Claudia's integration of the biological with the anthropological. This was one of the best classes I've ever taken at Yale. 

Weaknesses -- I literally can't think of a single one.
Only strengths! The class prioritizes learning over rote memorization. Professor Valeggia is the best professor. She and the design of the class are amazing
strengths: highly flexible assignment deadlines, personal and flexible classroom experience, low-stress readings.
No weaknesses! I honestly loved and valued each class.
There aren't many classes like this one at Yale, and that's its strengthit's not conducted traditionally and allows for the students to interact with class content in a full way.
This is an amazing course! Claudia is an absolutely wonderful professor, and ensures that every student feels welcome and worthy in her class.
Claudia cultivated an amazing and anti-stress learning environment. All learning was done for the sake of learning, and not for any grade motivation.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely- I recommend this course to everyone I know. I learned more in this class than almost any other I've taken at Yale, knowledge that has already personally benefitted me and those around me and will continue to do so.
YES! Amazing. Professor Valeggia is one of the best professor's I have ever had.
YES YES YES!!!
Yes! This class is amazing and so is Professor Valeggia. You will learn so much about female reproductive health and so much fascinating information.
Yes! Anyone who wants to learn from a fabulous Professor should take this course.

Absolutely!! The way Professor Valeggia designs the course means that you will learn because you want to, not because you have to. At the end of every week you'll find yourself wondering: why didn't I know that?? Material is consistently fascinating and Professor Valeggia is wonderful. Course is highly accessible for those--like me--who have little to no science background, and is also well-designed for those who do.

YESYESYESYESYESYESYES. I think every student at Yale should take this class. It is such a great example of how important medical anthropology is. I was FASCINATED by every single lecture and reading. PLEASE TAKE THIS CLASS.
Yes. Whatever major you are, you will benefit from this course. Take it if you can!
I would recommend if you're looking for a science credit that allows you to be creative in your approach and engagement with the materials!
Yes!! I cant recommend this course enough, this was by far the most informative, useful, and empowering class I've taken at Yale.

YES!!! If youre lucky enough to get into this class you MUST take it  Claudia and the teaching staff are so knowledgeable, supportive, and kind; the assignments are meaningful and creative and also deadlines are super flexible; learn very important topics that impact how to better understand reproductive health  what you learn from this class will be applicable to everyday life!! You learn so much :))
YES! Excellent science course for non-stem students, and excellent course in general.
Yes! Best science credit ever
Yes!!!! 100 times yes!
Absolutely. A must take. Do yourself a favor and add this to your bucket list.
